newsitem.title: GERMANY: Buba's Kuehbacher says no Italy in EMU from start.
newsitem.headline: Buba's Kuehbacher says no Italy in EMU from start.

text.p: Italy should not take part in European currency union from the beginning, Bundesbank council member Klaus-Dieter Kuehbacher, said on Monday.
"The Italians want to get in, but they shouldn't get in," Kuehbacher, also president of the Berlin-Brandenburg state central bank, said at a meeting of the German social democratic party, the SPD.
Kuehbacher said that Italy did not yet meet the fiscal requirements for monetary union, adding that he thought that Greece would also not be taking part from the start.
On the other hand, there was no doubt that Germany and France would be participating from the outset, Kuehbacher said.
European monetary union would lead to the development of a second world currency with the dollar, which would attract international investor interest.

However, central to the success of the currency was its acceptance by the general populace. If private investors lose confidence in their domestic currencies and flee to the dollar, then it would lead to a disaster, Kuehbacher said.
Kuehbacher ruled out a possible postponement of the 1999 start date for currency union.
